private_information: I follow standard BlocksWorld rules: only the top block of a stack may be moved and only one block can be carried at a time.
I have been assigned the odd-numbered actions from the provided sequence and will execute them in order.

Assigned actions: [1: unstack(D, E), 3: unstack(K, A), 5: unstack(K, J), 7: unstack(J, G), 9: unstack(K, D), 11: unstack(J, A), 13: unstack(K, D), 15: pickup(K), 17: unstack(G, I), 19: pickup(J), 21: unstack(D, E), 23: unstack(E, L), 25: unstack(I, F), 27: pickup(I), 29: unstack(E, D), 31: unstack(E, L), 33: unstack(I, F), 35: unstack(L, C), 37: pickup(F), 39: pickup(F), 41: unstack(F, C), 43: unstack(L, I), 45: pickup(F), 47: pickup(F), 49: unstack(F, L)]
manipulator1.goal: Execute each assigned action in sequence and produce an observation report describing the state of stacks after each action.

private_information: I follow standard BlocksWorld rules: only the top block of a stack may be moved and only one block can be carried at a time.
I have been assigned the even-numbered actions from the provided sequence and will execute them in order.

Assigned actions: [2: stack(D, E), 4: stack(K, J), 6: stack(K, D), 8: stack(J, A), 10: stack(K, D), 12: putdown(J), 14: putdown(K), 16: stack(K, A), 18: stack(G, K), 20: stack(J, G), 22: stack(D, J), 24: stack(E, D), 26: putdown(I), 28: stack(I, F), 30: stack(E, L), 32: stack(E, D), 34: stack(I, E), 36: stack(L, I), 38: putdown(F), 40: stack(F, C), 42: putdown(F), 44: stack(L, I), 46: putdown(F), 48: stack(F, L), 50: stack(F, C)]
manipulator2.goal: Execute each assigned action in sequence and produce an observation report describing the state of stacks after each action.

private_information: I will integrate the observations produced by the two manipulators, resolve any ordering questions, and produce a final PDDL domain and problem file targeted for the FastDownwards solver.
I must keep the action responsibilities of manipulators distinct and reflect the final arrangement as the initial state of the PDDL problem.
orchestrator.goal: Integrate the manipulators' observation reports and emit a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem (suitable for FastDownwards) that encode the final arrangement reached after the full sequence of actions.

public_information: Problem type: Standard BlocksWorld. Only the top block of a stack can be moved and only one block may be carried at a time.
Action sequence (50 actions) will be executed in the given order by the two manipulators.
Final arrangement derived from executing the full sequence:

observation.system_prompt: You are a BlocksWorld operator agent that executes a predefined list of actions. For each action you perform, report the action and the resulting configuration as a concise state description mapping each block to the thing it is immediately on (another block or the table). Do not emit PDDL.
observation.prompt: You are manipulator1. Use the public information about blocks and the standard BlocksWorld rules. Execute your assigned actions in order and produce a chronological observation report. Each report entry should list the action taken and a concise mapping of every block to what it is directly on (example: "A on table", "B on H").

observation.system_prompt: You are a BlocksWorld operator agent that executes a predefined list of actions. For each action you perform, report the action and the resulting configuration as a concise state description mapping each block to the thing it is immediately on (another block or the table). Do not emit PDDL.
observation.prompt: You are manipulator2. Use the public information about blocks and the standard BlocksWorld rules. Execute your assigned actions in order and produce a chronological observation report. Each report entry should list the action taken and a concise mapping of every block to what it is directly on (example: "A on table", "B on H").

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert multi-agent integrator and PDDL author. Your job is to read the two observation reports from the manipulators, reconcile them into a single consistent final state, and then produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem file suitable for the FastDownwards planner. Keep the manipulators' actions distinct in the explanations but encode only the final arrangement as the initial state in the problem file. Provide a STRIPS-compatible domain using standard blocks predicates (on, ontable, clear, holding, handempty) and include the problem file with the final arrangement in the initial section and a suitably stated goal (for example, you may use an empty goal or a goal that asserts the same final arrangement to allow validation by FastDownwards). Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. Integrate the two observation reports and compute the single consistent final arrangement of the blocks after the full sequence. Then output a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem targeted for FastDownwards. The domain must be STRIPS-compatible and define actions pickup, putdown, stack, unstack with appropriate preconditions and effects. The problem must list objects (the 12 blocks), the initial predicates that reflect the final arrangement, and a goal suitable for validating the resulting state. Enclose the domain in <domain></domain> and the problem in <problem></problem>. If there are ambiguities in the reports, explain them concisely and choose the interpretation consistent with the execution order; preserve manipulator action ownership when describing how the final state was reached.
